Every concept I write is in a box to the left, and next to the box I write the noun correspondent to the concept. So for example, if the concept was 'pencil', the word 'PENCIL' would be inside a box to the left, and next to it would be written 'OBJECT used for writing.' You can add adjectives later on, but I try to keep only the essential information. This makes the concept's importance visually obvious, links the name of the concept and the noun that explains what it is talking about, and helps with photographic memory.

Output is just as important as input.

These Crash Course videos are fantastic, and I appreciate them so much. These are all great tips, and I think I'm going to start implementing some of the Cornell method into my notes.

I do think, at least for me, that the number one factor for taking good notes has been reading prior to class. I've tried a few different ways, and found I either write too much or too little, and when I review my notes I don't really have a strong recollection of what I write anyway. It's like so much energy goes into simply taking the notes. But reading beforehand (seeing slides, or even scanning the headings to be covered in lecture) gives me the opportunity to see the overarching ideas and connect them, it also allows me to know what material is expanded on in text or slides and what is new material presented by the teacher (which often is tested later). One challenge is setting aside the time, but I also find I'm able to focus more when I preread and I think it saves some cramming stress.

Another tip I might recommend is the audio recording. In class is a really different environment from the study environment (and there's some evidence linking retention to specific environments) (plus distractions), and if you are allowed to record I would recommend doing so because it gives you the opportunity to catch things you miss, and to actively listen. I personally find I take a lot more away from classes where I'm just listening instead of recording down info that I'll eventually study more thoroughly in a text later.

*Notes*: Taking notes during lectures is important because its helps one retain information as well as serve as a guide to look back on later for class concepts. There are several ways to take notes; electronically, on paper, the outline method, mind-mapping, the Cornell method, and several others. There are some advantages the methods have over others, but ultimately one has the gauge early on what method works best for them in a context  (math and history notes will look different, right?). However, there are some tips for note taking that generally work for different methods: pay attention & write down the important stuff (big ideas, terms, concepts, etc), especially if the lecturer explicitly states so.

I typically use a hybrid between outline and Cornell notes. I keep the list structure of outline notes, but instead of indenting lines to differentiate topics, subtopics, and details, I use the left column of Cornell notes. Here I write down the topic and specific side details that help identify it. EMF, or electromotive force, notated as ε, goes in the left. Details about it, like how it is voltage, etc. goes in the right. If there's math involved, it goes in an example below with Ex: written on the line between the two sections. Then eventually at the bottom I have a written summary similar to the end of Crash Course Chemistry videos.

This is pretty good but it doesn't answer the important question I always had talking notes when in school or college. My biggest issues always where running out of room in my notebook or not noticing when a professor is shifting back and forth between subjects coupled with my slow hand writing affecting how much info I can gather in real time. It became annoy so I stopped trying so hard and found out a lot of my notes where unorganized or included to much or to little information.
To me the Cornell is pretty flawed because it asked me to split the page into three sections with little understanding of how much information should go where as to not fill up or waste to much page space. Outline method is good but deciding on line breaks when moving on to new subjects doesn't leave much flexibility. What if I wanna add information? What if I changed my mind on the subject and wanna edit the notes in real time? Nope no room on the page line for that.

I have my own method of note taking and it's some kind of hybrid monster of the outline method and the mind map method
I'm very careful about one thing: I have a visual memory, I like to draw and I'm creative. It's one of the different types of memories (some people have audio memory, reading memory etc...)
So I took it into account! I also tend to get bored and distracted when I study and read my notes at home so having all of my pages looking the same doesnt' work.

The best examples of my method are my philosophy class notes. I write in blue, and when the teacher is going slightly off topic or giving more detailed information about something very specific, I write in black.

I never make full sentences (too slow) and I start each sentence at the beginning of a new line, I also have my own abbreviations, I allow myself a lot of wiggle room, like for example if a word is too long (classes are in French and french word are sometimes very long), write it in another language

then, if I feel like what the teacher is saying is related/about the previous things, I make an indent and continue writing further from the vertical red line.
I also use lines to connect elements that aren't written next to each other.

Then, when I read my notes again, I use highlighters to categorize things: Authors in blue, quotes in yellow, new words in pink, key words in green...

Consequently, the word density on my pages is very light (I use more pages but that's another problem) so it doesn't look overwhelming when I have to read them again!

The point is, you have to use the method that fits best to your memory type <3

Great video. My own experience has led me to adopt a hybrid note-taking method, pretty much just by combining elements from each of the methods described here. I would say my notes are  60 % outline, 30% mind-map, and 10% Pauk. I am able to do this because I use pen and paper which allows me to draw arrows and lines across the paper, shapes around kew words, as well as figures and words on the side. I like the meta-cognition or thinking about thinking approaches of Pauk's method as I note cues or contextual words that will help me to recall what I had learned earlier during the semester. Also, I try to summarize entire lectures or chapters in several precisely and well-worded sentences. The outline is good because it's general and often familiar. It's rigid but if you use a pen and paper it is easy to make it less so.

hey yall!! i'm team handwritten note all they way and over the years, i've developed a few tips and tricks i thought i'd share, bc they help me TONS. (currently an AP high school student, for reference)

1. during, class, get the information down as quick as you can and as detailed as you can, but make sure you listen to what your teacher is teaching. do not get distracted by formatting your notes in class- just get the words on the paper. (you could also do this step on a computer- then switch to handwritten notes for the next steps!)
2. these "first draft" notes, (i call mine ugly notes, bc well, they're ugly haha), use these to STUDY. at the end of the day, or a few days before your quiz/test, start REWRITING THEM.
3. rewrite all the info using your nice handwriting, bubble letters for titles, little doodles, colour coordination, highlighters, GO ALL OUT. i promise this works, here's why:
4. when you rewrite your notes, it forces you to go over the information you learned in class. you're rewriting them on your own time, not having to worry about your prof changing slides, so you can take your time to review the information, add details, and organize the info in a a way that works with how it looks on the paper.
5. by spending time colour coordinating, adding doodles relevant to the info, and adding fancy organized bullet lists, you'll remember the way the info looks on your page. (i.e,... remembering the 3 main points your teacher told you about x topic, because a was pink, b was purple, c was blue.)

honestly, putting aside study time to rewrite my notes was i n c r e d i b l y helpful for me, and i seriously had fun doing it. when your notes are neat, fancy, and detailed (which you likely can't do while in class during a lecture) it's easy to organize ideas, connect info, and quiz yourself (or get your friends to quiz you!). physically writing down the info more than once makes it stick in your brain, and it's way more effective than just reading and rereading. personalize your notes and studying won't be so dreadful. (:

I liked this video as a means to organize thoughts and ideas. A couple of ideas were actually inferred in this video that I'd like to 'verbalize'. Firstly, when testing students, we can break questions into three categories: (1) Wrote memorization, (2) Procedural memorization, (3) Critical thinking. Note taking should cover the last aspect and avoid the first two. Why? Because the first two are easy to find via references (i.e. Textbooks, standards, etc.) Focusing on "how to use the information" is critical. While this is extremely important in the sciences, it stays true for history, religion, politics and the like.

The second idea is that people learn in different ways.  We learn by doing (touching), hearing and seeing. These ultimately add up to "thinking". Each person is unique in the needed amount of these senses for concepts to stick. Therefore, a note taking style needs to supplement the way that you learn. For example, I am a visual learner; as long as I can visualize a concept, I can learn it. However, for it to enter long term storage, I need to do it. In addition, I can only set critical thinking by 'using' this information on a new problem.

My point to this discourse is to supplement your video by providing additional information. First, good note taking skills start by understanding the concept as the lecture unfolds. Only then should you write things down and in a manner that supplements the learning materials. Secondly, note taking style needs to blend with the topic and the individuals learning style.

Again, this was a great video that teaches an essential study skill! Keep up the good work!

All of these ways to take notes are great, but there's one I think should have been added for the few of us that really need it: "Tape Recorder"

I have a slight learning disability where if I don't give 100% attention to listening to the lecture then I'd miss chunks of what was being said. So, every time I went to write anything, I'd miss what the teacher was saying while (s)he moved on.

I would therefore record the lecture, either on actual tape or using my laptop w/ free software like Audacity, and then go home to write the notes from the recording. This ensured I would not only have great notes, but I would retain much more of the lecture as well.

If any one wants advice on taking notes, heres how I do it (generally on a computer but it worked well on paper too!) Basically I make my notes visually interesting to look at. If you've seen aesthetic note taking, you know what i'm talking about. I generally divide the page into two columns and i fill it up with headings and bullet points as different topics come along, I dont like to go anymore than one level of sub bullet because otherwise it gets messy. Then when there's important info, I put it in a box of some sort. Normally I will decorate the boxes and bullet points and headings with aesthetic colors to make it pretty!

I have always been told that old fashioned pen/pencil and paper is the best. When you write it down your mind makes a mental note of what you wrote down so you can be more prepared for a test. If you are ADD/ADHD or any other type of learning disablilities you can get "accomidations" and sometimes teachers legally have to abide to these accomidations.
EXAMPLE:
•write history notes in blue then ask the teacher to use blue paper for your history test or ask if you can use a blue highliter to higlite the history questions....... (same for history etc)
•use colored flashcards
•use colored highliters

Its probably worth noting that if you're either a maths or physics student you don't gain any advantage on a laptop in terms of speed particularly in examples, unless there's a free app I'm missing it's way too difficult to type complex functions or what you're doing in shorthand on a computer.

In terms of how I actually write my notes it partially depends on the lecure I'm in, if you're teacher/lecturer is good the lecture has a structure that makes sense on it's own anyway so if you follow along the major topics and sub topics tend to organise themselves.
In examples I tend to copy on the left side of the page the steps to the problem (Including extra steps if they're skimmed over) and on the right side of the page I write in shorthand what I've done otherwise you can easily forget how you did a step if there's a jump in the problem Ie simply write DIF chain, when differentiating by chain method. Otherwise you'll often look back at examples and think how did I get from x to y?! because your notes are unclear.

Also use more than one colour damnit it makes your notes way less boring to look at.

If you're a visual learner, and like seeing ideas interconnected, I definitely recommend the brain map. I used this in English class, when we were discussing the book we were studying. It was amazingly helpful, it helped link different aspects and themes that I might otherwise not have noticed, and helped me remember it so much better. After my original messy notes that I took during class, I would go back, redraw in a neater fashion, add other little nuggets of info I might not have put in, and color coded the big blocks of connected information.

I have never been able to study with mind maps or those kind of stratified notes. It gets annoying for me and checking that everything is perfectly symmetric distracts me a lot (you know, how do you make a mind map were every branch is not exactly symmetric to the others in terms of position and content???!!).
I study better writing my notes in paragraphs. All my notebooks look the same, just paragraph after paragraph of mostly plain black text. But organizing ideas like that is how I study better. I use a green pen to write words for concepts (the actual definition is in regular black), I use red to specific anatomy structures, and blue pen to describe processes. Everything else is just black.

A few thoughts on paper note-taking:
1) the choice of pen or pencil is important!
- erase-ability can be key to keeping your notes legible and neat.
- some people like to use colored pens or pencils, but don't go overboard! if you're spending more time choosing which color to use than actually taking notes, you may want to limit yourself to one main color plus 1-3 extra colors if needed. (for instance, i took my biology notes in pencil, but used blue and red ink pens for diagrams.)
2) paper choice is important too!
- using the correct line width (aka wide or college ruled) to fit your handwriting makes note taking much easier.
- using lined paper isn't always the best choice either! if your notes are going to be diagram/drawing heavy, unlined might be better. for a math or science class, i always recommend engineering paper, as it is lined like graph paper, but with lighter lines so that its easier to see what is actually written on the page.
3) ALWAYS DATE YOUR NOTES. ALWAYS.

I've been teaching for 20 years and used to let students try a number of systems. I've seen firsthand that handwritten notes are so much better for learning than either typing notes in class or recording audio for transcription later. As far as I know, every study in the last decade or so confirms what I saw in my own classrooms.

These days, I simply don't allow typing or pictures and make sure my students learn several different styles of note taking so they can find the one that works best for them. And given that many college professors (and sometimes whole departments) ban typing, pics and audio recordings from their lectures, it's super-important to arrive at college with strong note-taking skills.

I really wish Thomas had made a stronger case for handwritten, since he knows as well as I do that one method is demonstrably superior. He has a responsibility to his viewers.

Meh. How to take notes, a shorter version for those that are busy.
Step 1: Get OneNote (full version not student or OneNote App)
Step 2: Start an audio recording at the start of the lecture.
Step 3: Jot down small 1 sentence points in the program to create a "map" or write down the examples.
Step 4: End the recording when the lecture is over.

What this lets you do is, when you go back to the recording, you can click on something you wrote, and OneNote, will jump to the part of the recording that was going on at the time of you writing that point. I use it for Stats and Calculus like a boss. Now all you have to do is re-write your notes using any traditional note taking format.

When you write notes, and by "write" I mean cursive, not printing (printing is for kids 9 and younger), you increase retention because you brain is more active in the act. Each letter requires a different shape whereas in typing, each letter just requires a tap. Your muscles are not used differently for every letter... Also there is a flow in writing (cursive) that is more akin to a flow of thoughts or the flow of speech than is childish printing or  typing. Not only does cursive lead to increased brain activity, it is associated with long-term information retention (the purpose of notes), better thought organization, and increased ability to generate ideas. In other words, people who can't write in cursive aren't as... smart? If I were conducting job interviews and people printed their signature on the application... I wouldn't hire them. LOL

It seriously depends on the content of the course when it comes to pen+paper vs computer. My first year at college I only used pen/pencil+paper with very little computer (only 1 business course) and then I changed to typing everythin sometime during the last year. For courses like Discrete Structures II (a type of probability course for CS students) and Information and Data Managament (a course mainly revolving around databases with various stuff like ER diagrams and relational algebra) it was quite difficult because various symbols and designs are difficult to replicate with plain text. However, I feel that for my business courses, typing was better because I could type a lot of information easily. The main reason I like typing is that it's easier to search for notes, but in some cases it simply isn't feasable (unless you can handwrite on an electronic device, which I've seen quite a few people start doing recently)

Pro-tip from someone who has managed to pass high school: a few days, or sometimes even the day before, write what I call "everything you need to know". Open your notes and have a separate sheet of paper next to you. Go through your notes and pull out the most important information. Write titles, drawings, anything you think you need. Put it all on the sheet. Honestly, it really helps to put things to memory.

I'm about to start my 2nd semester of my second bachelor's degree (25 years after graduating from my first degree).  In my first degree, my strategy was to write as fast as possible to get as much as possible on paper.  Now, my strategy is to write as little as possible (mostly just topic headings).  Why?  Because every second I'm writing is a second that I'm not paying attention to the lecture.  I'm in "copy mode" where my brain is trying to form the sentence or phrase that I'm writing and, simultaneously, trying to understand a new concept presented by the professor.  That doesn't work.  But, my strategy also involves reading and understanding the chapter in the text very thoroughly (before the lecture).  In other words, my learning is 90% from the textbook and the 10% from lectures is just verifying that I understood the book.  It also helps that I'm a half-time student and have tons of time to study.

I always hated when my high school teachers would force us to use cornell notes because I'd get really anxious about running out of space, and it would distract me from the actual lecture. What I learned to do instead was to write my notes double spaced, and then I could write comments, questions, definitions, and summery statements later in the off-lines, in different colors. This left me with very clear and readable notes, the ability to comment and revisit notes, and I never had to worry about sectioning off space on the page :).

Hey, thanks for doing this series! I've needed this for quite a long time, but I've been lucky enough to get A's in high school without studying very hard. Now those A's are turning to B's and C's in college, and I'm desperate for better methods. That brings me to note-taking methods. I like the Cornell Method conceptually, but it requires knowledge of how much information will be discussed in class BEFORE the notes are taken. That is, how big should I make the Notes and Cues parts of the paper? That's why I use the Outline Method: I can add information as I please, but it doesn't relate the concepts to each other, and I often find myself skipping information (mostly examples) because I want to keep certain concepts close to each other on the page. But the Mind Map Method has the same problem as the Cornell Method. Is there a method that is still highly organized but keeps important concepts close to each other physically? Is there a method that doesn't have any of the problems I cited?

TL;DR Is there another note-taking method that (1) is highly organized, (2) doesn't incentivize skipping information, (3) has no physical constraints on the page, and (4) keeps important concepts physically close on the page?

I can vouch for the Summary section. I used loose outline style in uni, then after class went back and recopied my notes in better handwriting, with better sketches, and included summaries and extra notes in the second version to help with understanding. Additional notes ended up being key to me. Writing down not just what the professor puts in the powerpoint or on the board during lecture, but adding little extra thoughts on the side to remind you what's going on in an example.

The rest of the Cornell Method looks terrible to me, though. What is that even supposed to be? (EDIT: Googled it and it turns out they just used an ugly image to demonstrate the page layout. It seems close to a normal outline format, just with extra space on the side and bottom for cues and summaries.)

I'm in university and I've noticed that it gets to a point where you do a lot of this without noticing.
My notes are nowhere near as neat and pretty as yours, though and I almost always use pen and paper, I cannot type as fast.
I feel like the greatest barrier to taking notes is how hard it can be, at least for me. And how demotivating that is, especially if the class is interesting. Taking notes takes up a portion of your attention that tires you more than if you just listened closely, and sometimes makes it harder to understand everything, because you're too worried trying to get it all down.
I find that it's important to know WHEN to take notes. Especially if you've already read the material before class, it makes more sense to focus on that which wasn't in there or hadn't been so clear while studying or which complements what you already know, or simple clues as to what the topics are, so that you'll remember they're important and go look them up in your book or just remember the class itself. In-depth summaries are better left for after class, when you can devote your entire attention to them.
